item.title: Smart Player API sample: Are you still watching?
item.description:
A new Smart Player API sample that shows how to detect when the viewer has stopped watching, but left the video player playing. A message displays over the video player. If the viewer clicks it within a specfied time, playback continues; otherwise the video is paused.

The technique is useful if you have long-form content, or a playlist with auto-advance enabled, and do not want to waste bandwidth on viewers who start the video and then leave it to do something else without bothering to stop it.

item.title: Navigate On Video End
item.description: This example will navigate to a new URL when the video has finished playing. We use the Smart Player API getCurrentVideo() method to retrieve the data for the video that is currently loaded in the player. From the video object, we get the new destination's URL from the linkURL property. We then use the window.location object's href property to redirect the browser to the URL.

We use the getPlaylistByID() method to find all of the videos associated with each playlist, and then load this data into three horizontal scrollers; one scroller for each playlist. When the user selects a video from the scroller, we use the loadVideoByID() method to load and play the selected video. The jQuery jsCarousel content slider plugin is used to create the horizontal scrollers.

item.title: CORS
item.description: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that allows a web page to make requests to another domain other than the one from which the page was served. Normally cross-domain requests would otherwise be forbidden by web browsers. CORS defines a way domains can interact to determine whether or not to allow a cross-origin requests. There are two instances when CORS must be used with Brightcove services/products: *Captions for videos: The file that contains captions for a video can be stored on a non-Brightcove domain. Since the video itself will be served from a Brightcove domain, this will cause cross-domain issues. *New player and HLS: The new player's HLS plugin uses AJAX requests to retrieve the HLS video's manifest and individual segments. Since these HLS resources can be stored on any Internet accessible domain, it is likely these resources will be served from a different server than from the Brightcove domain that served the player. This will again cause cross-domain issues.

item.description: This is sample of using the Data Collection API to save analytics data for videos played in a non-Brightcove player (in this case, the Video.js player).
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Video Cloud Analytics Event Tracking
item.description: The Analytics Data Collection API allows you to add events to your Video Cloud Analytics data in situations where Brightcove cannot track the events directly. Please contact your account manager if you are interested in using this API.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Data Collection API
item.description: The Analytics Data Collection API allows you to add events to your Video Cloud Analytics data in situations where Brightcove cannot track the events directly.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Embeds Guide - Major Content Addition
item.description: By default when you create an embed, data in the embed overrides like data that would otherwise be inherited from the common player. For instance, if you have a poster field in the common player and poster field in the embed, the resulting poster field value will be the one from the embed. This situation is different for fields that contain arrays. When the data type of the field is an array, you can choose the inheritance behavior to be overwrite, prepend or append.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: New Brightcove Player: Player Configuration Guide - Major Content Addition
item.description: Content expanded to include information on autoplay, fullscreenControl, inactive player and CSS color overrides
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Live HLS
item.description: You can play a live HLS video stream through the new player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Plugin Guide - Major Content Addition
item.description: Content added about default plugins and the options property
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Developer Docs Update
item.description: The developer documentation site has been reorganized. There is now a Brightcove Player category and a Player Management category. We found having both categories under "Next Gen Player" was leading to confusion regarding new player docs vs. player management docs. We also reorganized the sub-categories within both of these main categories for consistency. Finally, breadcrumbs in the navigation have been added to better orient readers to document context.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Responsive Sizing for Video Players
item.description: This document was moved from the support site to developer docs. Code was moved into gists for easier reading and copying. Document description: When you embed a video player in a page, you will notice that it does not resize with the browser window. This occurs because, by default, the video player is given a fixed width and height, preventing it from responding to changes in the browser. One aspect of responsive web design is ensuring that elements within your page adapt gracefully to different screen sizes.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Quick Start to Plugin Development
item.description: This document provides a hands-on introduction to plugin development and use. See the Quick Start to Player Management for an introduction to creating a player and using an existing plugin.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Pass Data to the Plugin
item.description: In this document you will see how you can pass data to the plugin for use at plugin initialization.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Display Thumbnail Previews Plugin
item.description: The thumbnail previews plugin allows for the timeline to display a preview image at defined points for your video. The user can mouse over the timeline and images defined by you will be displayed for specified time ranges.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Compatibility and Known Issues
item.description: The following are known issues with the new player and various platforms/applications.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for Android Update
item.description: 4.1.17 updates
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Display Playlists in Scrollers
item.description: This sample uses the Smart Player API to display playlists in multiple horizontal scrollers. We use the getPlaylistByID() method to find all of the videos associated with each playlist, and then load this data into three horizontal scrollers; one scroller for each playlist. When the user selects a video from the scroller, we use the loadVideoByID() method to load and play the selected video. The jQuery jsCarousel content slider plugin is used to create the horizontal scrollers.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Display Error Messages Plugin
item.description: The error messages plugin allows the player to display user-friendly messages when it encounters an error. The default style sheet displays messages as a semi-transparent overlay on top of the video element itself. You can change existing message text and add your own styles. You can even create custom messages that are triggered when you want.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Display Overlay Plugin
item.description: The overlay plugin allows the player to display simple messages as a semi-transparent overlay on top of the video element. You can control the display of an overlay message based on a player event, such as play, pause and custom events, or based on a time interval during video playback.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Responsive Sizing for the Brightcove player
item.description: When you embed a video player in a page, you will notice that it does not resize with the browser window. This occurs because, by default, the video player is given a fixed width and height, preventing it from responding to changes in the browser. One aspect of responsive web design is ensuring that elements within your page adapt gracefully to different screen sizes. This document focuses on resizing video players according to screen dimensions, while also maintaining the aspect ratio, so that the video is not letterboxed.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Deep Linking
item.description: Deep linking is a feature that allows a user to start viewing a video from a specific time offset. This is a very useful feature for sharing a video like a newscast where the user may want people to view a certain segment of the program without having to watch everything that precedes it.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Generate Sitemaps
item.description: There is a standard document, called a sitemap, that search engine indexers look for when examining your site. The sitemap concisely tells the search engines what content is exposed on your site, the metadata for that content, and where that content is located on your site. A sitemap is an XML file that follows a standard specification.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Merged Configurations API
item.description: This document is NOT in any navigation menu at this time. We feel it is a rare enough use case that it is only linked to from other docs for added detail on the topic: There are four ways to combine published and preview versions of a parent and child player. The four combinations are: published parent - published child published parent - preview child preview parent - published child preview parent - preview child This document will detail how to use the merged configurations API to view the merged JSON configurations for each possible combination. Note that this is simply a way to view merged configurations, and has no effect on any player. Although using this API is not a common use case for most customers, it can be helpful in complex situations, for instance where you are using advanced array merging using array_prepend or array_append. This array merging technique is detailed in the Embed APIs Guide.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OnceUX VMAP for Twitter Amplify
item.description: OnceUX VMAP for Twitter Amplify is an extension to Brightcoveâ€™s OnceUX service. It is built upon the IAB VMAP 1.0 specification which is consumable by Twitterâ€™s video player in iOS, Android and desktop applications. Utilizing native Once device detection and decisioning logic, or alternatively when explicitly requesting the Amplify format, the service will respond to the client with the applicable VMAP 1.0 XML and video content based upon in-request or preconfigured business logic as detailed within this document.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Use Postman for HTTP Requests
item.description: Some find curl statements and the command line, used for most of the examples in this section of the documentation, difficult and intimidating. For those, there are numerous tools to send HTTP requests to a REST-based service. This document will show you how to use one such tool, the Chrome extension Postman, to send requests to the Player Management API.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Players Module
item.description: For the beta program: The Players Module is the Video Cloud Studio interface for the next generation Brightcove player.

item.title: Smart Player API Samples: Custom Overlay Plugin
item.description: This sample uses a JavaScript plugin to add custom overlays to a Video Cloud player. While the video is playing, an overlay displays clickable scrolling text. When the video stops, an overlay displays a clickable icon and text prompting the user to like the video on FaceBook.

item.title: Smart Player API Samples: Use Full Browser Window Width on Play
item.description: This example shows how to expand the Brightcove smart player to the full width of the browser window on play, while maintaining the aspect ratio.

item.description: This sample fetches playlists from the Video Cloud media library and displays them in a tabbed navigation. When the user selects a video from a playlist, it is displayed in the player along with associated metadata.

item.title: Quick Start to Using IMA Ads
item.description: To utilize ads with the Brightcove Player there are a number of tasks to perform. The first is establishing a relationship with an advertisement provider, such as Google or FreeWheel. Once you have an ad provider, you can proceed to utilize those ads with the Brightcove Player. At a high level, you must perform the following to use ads in the Brightcove Player: *Confirm the ad tag is valid *Load the IMA3 plugin into the Brightcove Player *Provide configuration options to the plugin, either at player initialization or dynamically
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove OAuth Overview
item.description: Brightcove's implementation of OAuth2 allows you to get access tokens for various Brightcove APIs.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OAuth Quick Start
item.description: This tutorial guides you through the steps to create a basic proxy in Node.js that gets an access_token for a Brightcove API, makes the API call, and returns the response data and headers (or error if something goes wrong). If you haven't yet looked at the OAuth Overview, it would be a good idea to look at it before proceeding.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OAuth: Get Client Credentials Using CURL
item.description: This tutorial guides you through the steps to get a client_id and client_secret using curl. Your client_id and client_secret are used in getting an access_token, which provides the authorization to make a call to a particular Brightcove API. You can see an example of how the access_token is retrieved in the OAuth Quick Start.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OAuth: Get Client Credentials Using Postman
item.description: This tutorial guides you through the steps to get a client_id and client_secret using Postman, a popular add-on for the Chrome browser that is also available as a packaged Chrome app. Your client_id and client_secret are used in getting an access_token, which provides the authorization to make a call to a particular Brightcove API. You can see an example of how the access_token is retrieved in the OAuth Quick Start.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OAuth Quick Start
item.description: This tutorial guides you through the steps to create a basic proxy in Node.js that gets an access_token for a Brightcove API, makes the API call, and returns the response data and headers (or error if something goes wrong). If you haven't yet looked at the OAuth Overview, it would be a good idea to look at it before proceeding.

item.description: This sample demonstrates how to set metadata on the <video> tag using the HTML5 data- custom data attribute. You then write a plugin to retrieve and utilize the metadata.

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Dynamically Change Source Videos
item.description: It is a common use-case to dynamically change the video loaded in the player. This topic shows you how to do this using both the embed_in_page and the embed_code (iframe) implementations. When you select a button on the HTML page, the source video will change.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Lightbox with Scroller
item.description: This topic shows you how to create a lightbox and simple scroller with the Brightcove player.

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Load Multiple Videos
item.description: This topic shows you how to create a Brightcove player that loads successive videos from an array. The next video in the array is loaded when the current video finishes playing.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Loading the Player Dynamically
item.description: This topic describes how to load the Brightcove player dynamically, that is, on a user event and NOT in the startup HTML. In the working example here you can click the Add Player button to dynamically load the player and play a video.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Lightbox Carousel
item.description: This topic shows you how to create a lightbox with the Brightcove player. It uses a jQuery carousel to display a set of videos.

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Multiple Session Playback
item.description: This topic describes how to use the new Brightcove player to update a session cookie during playback to maintain the current position. When the player initially loads, a cookie will be checked for the last watched position of the video. If the cookie is present, the video will begin playing at that point. When the video finishes playing, the cookie will be set to zero.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Quick Start to Player Management
item.description: Note: Major update using Video Cloud integration, which also requires OAuth for security. The previous version using basic authentication is still in the Perform section of the docs: http://docs.brightcove.com/en/perform/player-management/guides/player-mgmt-quick-start.html In this quick start you will perform the following tasks: *Create a Node.js application to act as your OAuth security proxy. This proxy will use your access token to make calls to the needed APIs. *Obtain credentials to use the API. *Create a player. *Update a player by replacing the video it plays. *Customize a player by adding a plugin. *Display the configuration for a player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Size the Player
item.description: Major update: This topic shows you how to size your video and player using the iframe and embed_in_page implementations. There are two important concepts to keep in mind when sizing the video and the player: Aspect ratio â€“ The media width and height properties, set in your curl statement when creating a player, define the intrinsic video dimensions, also known as the aspect ratio. Player size â€“ The player width and height properties, set in the CSS or HTML code, control the size of the player. As you change the size of the player, it will use the intrinsic video dimensions to keep the controls positioned correctly.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Developer Forums
item.description: Developer forums located in section navigation for the appropriate sections (Analytics API, SDKs, Brightcove Player and Player Management)

item.description: Updated: In this quick start you will create an app in Android Development Tools which plays a single video, a video from a Brightcove Video Cloud account, and lastly videos from a Brightcove Video Cloud playlist, all using the Brightcove Player SDK for Android.

item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Creating a Video Loop
item.description: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player to make a video automatically replay. There are some situations where you may want to use a looping video. Keep in mind that a video that loops indefinitely can be distracting to viewers of your website. This example loops the video 5 times and then stops video playback. If you need to, you can easily change this example to loop indefinitely.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OnceUX Plugin
item.description: Using the OnceUX plugin with your Brightcove player, you can playback any Brightcove Once video. By default, the plugin enforces that all advertisements are watched and displays an ad count-down timer while they play. You can easily customize this plugin to use your own overlays and allow users to skip advertisements.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Quick Start to Dynamic Ingest
item.description: In this quick start you will perform the following tasks: *Use the Content Management System (CMS) API, create a video object . *Use the Dynamic Ingest (DI) API, create an ingest request using the ID returned from the CMS API and an HTTP POST method . *Verify the ingest request functioned correctly.

item.title: Standard Ingest Profiles
item.description: When creating a Dynamic Ingest request using the DI API you must supply profile which determine the number and type of renditions created by the ingest. The standard profiles from which you can choose are: *single-rendition *HD *ScreenCast *Standard *audio-only *UGC
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Navigate on Video End
item.description: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player that displays an overlay on video end, which when clicked navigates the page to a new URL.

item.description: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player with a simple age gate overlay. The user must certify their age by clicking on the overlay text before the video will play.

item.title: Stopping Other Players on the Page when a Video Starts
item.description: This example pauses other players on the same page when a video starts to play. This example loads all players on the page into an array and an event listener is added that listens for the PLAY event. When the PLAY event is detected, a function is called that will pause all other players on the page.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Load Video when Thumbnail Clicked
item.description: This example uses the Smart Player API's loadVideoByID() method to retrieve a video. When a thumbnail image is clicked (an HTML onclick event dispatched from one of the thumbnails), the loadVideoByID() method is used to retrieve the video and load it into the player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Solution: Scroll Player into View
item.description: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player which starts playing the video as soon as you fully scroll the player into view, and pauses the video when you scroll it out of view. We call the Brightcove player API's play() and pause() methods to start and stop the video based on the position of the player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.description: The Player Management API has rate limiting per each unique IP enabled. Following are the rate limits...

item.description: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player that detects when the viewer has stopped watching, while leaving the video playing. After a set amount of time, an overlay message is displayed. If the viewer clicks the messasge within a specified time, then playback continues. If not, the video is paused.

item.title: Using Dynamic Ingest with S3
item.description: Dynamic Ingest can pull videos from your Amazon S3 bucket. If your S3 content is accessible to Everyone, there is nothing you need to do. If your content is protected, however, you will need to add a bucket policy allowing Dynamic Ingest to access your videos. This document explains how to do that.

item.title: Brightcove Player Accessibility
item.description: Brightcove Player has numerous accessibility features, detailed below.

item.title: Once Error Messages
item.description: The Once system can notify you when there is an issue with one of your media items. This document details the meaning of the messages you receive.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Job Status API Overview
item.description: The Job Status API allows you to query the Once system and get back information about the status of a job in JSON format. The status request is defined by query string parameters, and you can obtain the status for any step of a job. The status returned will be: *PENDING *PROCESSING *ERROR *COMPLETE
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Video Data Endpoint
item.description: The video data endpoint provides a quick way of getting specific data for a particular video. Current requests will return the alltime views for the video. In the future, additional data may be returned. The primary use case for this end point would be delivering alltime views information to players on high-traffic pages, where making large volumes of regular requests to the Analytics API would be too slow.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Publishing Video Options
item.description: When you create a player you see three implementations for publishing the player. These implementations are: *URL *In-page embed *iframe Each of these implementations can take two approaches. In the first approach the video is statically bound to the player by including it in the player configuration itself. A second approach is to create the player with no built-in video metadata. This player can play many different videos; the video ID is passed to the player at runtime, via a URL parameter, video tag attribute or JavaScript APIs.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Batch Update Using CMS API
item.description: This is a sample of making batch updates to video metadata using the CMS Ingest API. To get access tokens and make the API calls, it uses a proxy built by Brightcove Learning services. The proxy run at solutions.brightcove.com:8006 (for the CMS API). You may also use this proxy for testing from localhost, but not for production - the proxy will only accept requests from Brightcove domains or localhost. See Oauth Quick Start for a guide to building a simple proxy of your own.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Batch Dynamic Ingest
item.description: This is a sample of batch ingest using the Dynamic Ingest API. To get access tokens and make the API calls, it uses proxies built by Brightcove Learning services. The proxies run at: *solutions.brightcove.com:8006 (for the CMS API) *solutions.brightcove.com:8004 (for the DI API) You may also use these proxies for testing from localhost, but not for production - the proxies will only accept requests from Brightcove domains or localhost. See Oauth Quick Start for a guide to building a simple proxy of your own.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: The mediainfo Property
item.description: *Perform version: http://docs.brightcove.com/en/perform/brightcove-player/guides/mediainfo.html *The mediainfo property is an object which contains information on the current media in the player. The property is created and populated when using Brightcove Player's load() method, which is part of the catalog library, documented in the Player Catalog Reference. The mediainfo property can also be populated in others ways, described later in this document. After the mediainfo object is populated you can use it for convenient data retrieval when wishing to display video information, like the video name or description. The object is also used in analytics collection.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.description: You can specify a callback URL to receive error notications in case anything goes wrong during the ingest process. The URL you specify should be for an app than can accept POST requests. The error notications will be sent in JSON format.

The document you are now reading instructs you how to implement code to inform users that a video is geo-filtered.

item.description: This guide shows you how to create a bootstrap plugin which adds functionality and styles at runtime. A typical use case for this dynamic code plugin would be if you or a partner maintains a JavaScript library and you want all players using this library to automatically update when the library changes without having to republish the players.

item.title: Dynamically Change Source Videos - Perform
item.description: It is a common use-case to dynamically change the video loaded in the player. This topic shows you how to do this using both the embed_in_page and the embed_code (iframe) implementations.

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for iOS update
item.description: 4.2.2 updates: Fixes a bug where the default controls playhead label will show a the incorrect playhead at the end of a video when running on device. Fixes a bug where the default controls slider isn't reset to 0 after calling advanceToNext or using AutoAdvance.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Using the CMS API: Add WebVTT Captions
item.description: Brightcove's CMS API allows you to add WebVTT captions to your video metadata. Note that WebVTT captions cannot be added when you initially create the video using a POST request. Instead they must be added using a PATCH request to update the video metadata. See Batch Update Using CMS API for an example of an update request.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Opting Out of Automatic Player Updates
item.description: This topic explains how to opt out of automatic player updates.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Convert Captions to WebVTT Format
item.description: This guide shows you how to install and use a Python-based tool to convert your closed captions file from DFXP/TTML to WebVTT format. You can also convert from and to other valid captions file formats.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: CMS API: Managing Notifications
item.description: You can receive notifications when any changes are made to your video library. Notifications will be sent to the URL you specify, which should point to an application capable of handling HTTP POST requests.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Localize Plugins
item.description: This topic shows how a plugin developer can localize a Brightcove Player plugin. Note that this is NOT the same as using the built-in localization for the player itself.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: CMS API Overview
item.description: Updated: Brightcove's CMS API provides a programmatic way to create, update and access data for your Video Cloud videos.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Understanding Player Events
item.description: The Brightcove player has many events for you to control video playback. This topic provides an overview about the different types of events.

item.title: Once Content Security
item.description: This document explains content security supported by Once.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Localize Brightcove Player
item.description: In this topic you will see how to localize Brightcove Player. This is, literally, hard to see as the names of the control elements do not appear as you hover over them. The localized names of the control elements would be used by a screen reader though. In this document you will use the player's HTML structure to confirm the elements' names have be localized. First the process for localizing the In-Page Embed implementation is shown, then the iframe implementation. The document concludes by demonstrating how to edit or add to localized vocabulary if wish to localize content on the page surrounding the player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.description: This is a reference to video fields returned by the CMS API.

item.description: Using the OnceUX plugin with your Brightcove player, you can playback any Brightcove Once video.

item.title: Major update: Responsive Sizing for the Brightcove Player
item.description: When you embed a video player in a page, you will notice that it does not resize with the browser window. This occurs because, by default, the video player is given a fixed width and height, preventing it from responding to changes in the browser. One aspect of responsive web design is ensuring that elements within your page adapt gracefully to different screen sizes.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.description: This document provides a hands-on introduction to using the IMA3 Plugin to display advertisements in Brightcove Player.

item.title: Dynamic Ingest API Overview: Updated section on notifications
item.description: You can specify a one or more callback URLs to receive notifications of the results of the ingest process. The URLs you specify should be for apps than can accept POST requests. Notifications will be sent in JSON format.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Flash Player API Bridge
item.description: This plugin exposes some methods of the Flash-only Player API to javascript. The intended use is for when you want to use the Smart Player API in the page, but need to access some functionality that is only implemented in the Flash-only player API.

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for iOS update
item.description: 4.3.0 updates: *Added BCOVAdvertising APIs. These APIs introduce the concept of Ads to our core SDK. Playback controller delegate and session consumer apis have also been added to provide ad information. In the future, our advertising plugins will be updated to provide ad events through these apis. For more information, please see the README.md. *BCOVPlaybackSession protocol now includes a providerExtention property. In the future, some of our plugins will be updated to provide plugin specific functionality through this property. *The default controls now include a closed caption button for testing. *Internal bug fixes.

item.description: This topic covers the use of the Custom Endscreen plugin and how it can be implemented using Video Cloud Studio and through custom coding. The plugin allows display of customer supplied HTML at the conclusion of video playback.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Native Video Playback
item.description: Understanding the various approaches of implementing video in your application will lay the foundation for your success. This document aims to outline the most common video player implementations at a high level with useful links to outside resources that can be used for additional research.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Advertising with the SDKs
item.description: The Brightcove iOS and Android Native Player SDKs offer a suite of options to help you monetize your content. The Native SDKs and their integrations enable publishers to decide how to best optimize the advertising in their player with features such as pre-, mid- and post-roll advertisements, as well as companion ads.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Digital Rights Management with the SDKs
item.description: Digital Rights Management (DRM) is a robust content protection program that enables publishers to enforce polices and rules for usage of their content. DRM encrypts your content, sets your license policies, and delivers your content via progressive download or streaming through a secure solution that's completely transparent to your viewers. It does not require passwords or plug-in installation from your viewers, and needs no maintenance from you as a publisher.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Analytics with the SDKs
item.description: With analytics data, you can track the success of your videos and better understand your viewer's habits. The Brightcove Native Player SDKs for iOS and Android make it easy to integrate analytics collection into your video solution.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Video Formats and Captioning
item.description: Understanding your options when choosing which video format to use and what captions to apply, is essential for ensuring your application will deliver the desired video experience to viewers. The Brightcove Native Player SDKs for mobile platforms strive to ensure your application reaches a wider audience and meets FCC guidelines by ensuring that your content provides an exceptional caption experience.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for iOS update
item.description: 4.3.1: The seek bar on the default controls is now disabled until the AVPlayer is capable of seeking.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Add Captions to Videos
item.description: New section added: It is possible to programmatically add text tracks for captions. The key method for this functionality is addRemoteTextTrack().
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Player Repositories
item.description: In order to publish players to a CDN the Player Management API utilizes the Delivery System API. The Delivery System API allows you to create a git repository, the contents of which get hosted on players.brightcove.net. When a player is created Brightcove creates a repository behind the scenes. Every time the player is re-published, whether directly requested by a publisher or when a Brightcove player update is released, there is a corresponding commit and push to that repository.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Driving Video Views Through Email
item.description: We often get asked about the best way to embed video inside of email. On most platforms, embedding videos directly into email isnâ€™t possible. This isn't a Brightcove limitation, nearly every modern email system will strip out video player embed code due to security reasons. We can however, drive awareness and traffic for content by creating an email with some teaser text and a thumbnail image. The thumbnail image will look like a video player and be a clickable link that redirects to our video landing page.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Using Cue Points
item.description: Cue points can be set for a video. During video playback, an event is dispatched when each cue point is hit.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: FreeWheel Plugin
item.description: This topic covers the use of the FreeWheel plugin, and how it can be implemented using Video Cloud Studio and through custom coding. This plugin enables FreeWheel ad technology, for either Flash or HTML5, in Brightcove Player. The plugin will attempt to select the best rendering option to be used for the lifetime of the player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Organizing Videos Using Folders
item.description: In this topic you will learn how to organize videos using folders inside the Media module. Folders can be used to organize videos inside of the Media module. Folders can be used to organize videos by subject, author, product, region, etc. Having videos in folders makes it easier to manage a Video Cloud account with hundreds or thousands of videos.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Capturing Events on Replay
item.description: This topic describes Capturing "begin" and "complete" events when the video is replayed. The Smart Player APIs' BEGIN and COMPLETE events fire only once per video load. If the viewer replays the video, these events will not be triggered a second time. This is intentional because it is the expected behavior for many existing analytics plugins that depend on the API.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Rendition Selection
item.description: For apps using the Brightcove Native Player SDK for iOS, there is a default rendition selection process when playing a video. When you retrieve videos from the Brightcove catalog or construct a BCOVVideo object with multiple BCOVSource elements, the player has to decide which BCOVSource (rendition) to play back.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com
item.category: Brightcove Native Player SDK for iOS

item.title: Rendition Selection
item.description: For apps using the Brightcove Native Player SDK for Android, there is a default rendition selection process when playing a video. When you retrieve videos from the Brightcove catalog, the player has to decide which source (rendition) to play back. This is implemented in the DefaultSourceSelectionController component.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com
item.category: Brightcove Native Player SDK for Android

item.title: Live DVRUX Plugin
item.description: The Live DVRUX plugin skins the Brightcove Player with DVRUX controls during playback of HLS live video. The plugin changes the appearance and behavior of Brightcove Player to provide a better experience during live HLS playback, focusing primarily on the addition of DVR controls. With this plugin, viewers can seek to earlier points in the HLS stream as available, and they can tell in a glance where they are relative to the video's current live point.

item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.description: What incoming video formats are compatible with Dynamic Ingest? Nearly everything! We know that itâ€™s difficult to predict what types of formats might be uploaded to your application, especially with user-generated content, so our goal is to accept every video format possible.

item.description: New section on how to get information about custom fields defined for the account: This CMS API provides uncached read access to the data. This is important for time-sensitive publishing workflows because you make a changes to videos and playlists using the CMS API and quickly read the data to verify that is correct.

item.title: Standard Ingest Profiles
item.description: Major Update: When creating a Dynamic Ingest request using the DI API you must supply a profile which determines the number and type of renditions created by the ingest.

item.title: Once VOD 2.0
item.description: Once VOD 2.0 is the next generation content ingest, life cycle management, media management and dynamic permutation layer (DPL) subsystem for web video monetization and global playback with Once. The new system offers many advantages over its predecessor including simple and modular ingestion formats, cloud-based workflows, faster publishing times, and advanced DPL capabilities for multiple stream formats and content security packaging.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Once-Ingest-API
item.description: The Dynamic Ingest (DI) API is used to retrieve a video asset and create renditions.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Once Media Management API
item.description: The Media Management API is a RESTful API for accessing and configuring the components of the domain for an authorized user. The multi-faceted and cascading configuration hierarchy gives the domain owner the ability to set-up domain, application, catalog and mediaitem level settings. The authorized user has the ability to create, read, update and delete anything from ad configurations to metadata on independent media items. It provides easy to use methods for fronting UI components in an existing CMS or through a programmatic function.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Once Status API
item.description: The Status API is a RESTful API which allows customers to query the processing statuses of a particular Request ID (returned in the response body of an ingest request). Only the HTTP GET verb is supported and must be made over SSL. If you do not know the Request ID you can query by Foreign Key, which will return a list of all the Request IDs for that particular item. The status data returned will be summary of the major milestones along with any errors that occurred during processing.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

Accessing the data programmatically gives you additional flexibility for such purposes as: *Creating custom charts and displays *Working with multiple APIs together - for example, getting video data using the CMS API for videos with the most views over the previous week *Combining your video analytic data with other site analytics data

item.title: Video Report by Reference ID
item.description: This sample allows you to get reports on videos by the video reference ID and return the results in JSON or CSV format.

item.title: Samples: Video Engagement Graph
item.description: This sample allows you to generate an engagement graph for a video in your account. Although you can generate an engagement graph from a video report, here we use a engagement request, because the response contains more complete data: rollups return engagement for every hundredth segment of the video, while a report returns only engagement at each quarter point of the video.

item.title: Identifying Low-Performing Content
item.description: This sample uses the Media API and the Analytics API together to compile a list of videos with less than five views over the past 1-6 months (you can specify the period). The output includes the creation date for the video, and you can exclude videos published within the last 1-12 months if you like. The results can be returned in JSON or CSV format.

item.description: New section in document: Meta tags - After you update your Brightcove player to use the social sharing plugin in the previous section, you are ready to add social meta tags to your HTML page. These meta tags allow social sharing sites to embed your video players and thumbnails in the post. The form below calls the CMS API with your information and retrieves your video data. It then generates social meta tags with your specific data.

item.description: This topic provides an overview of how to create and edit ingest profiles. Ingest profiles contain the transcode settings that will be used when videos are uploaded using the Upload module or the Dynamic Ingest API.

item.description: The Brightcove Native SDK for Android simplifies integration of video playback with Brightcove Video Cloud and many popular advertising, analytics, and DRM solutions. Note the navigation buttons at the bottom of the page will walk you through the getting started content.

item.title: Ingest Profiles API Overview
item.description: The Ingest Profiles API allows you to create, retrieve, update, and delete rendition profiles for your Video Cloud account. These profiles are used as a specification for transcoding when you upload or re-transcode videos.

item.title: Quick Start: Ingest Profiles API
item.description: The Ingest Profiles API allows you to manage ingest and transcode profiles for your account. This tutorial will walk you through these operations.

item.description: The Ingest Profiles API allows you to create, retrieve, update, and delete rendition profiles for your Video Cloud account. These profiles are used as a specification for transcoding when you upload or re-transcode videos.

item.description: This is a reference to fields for ingest profile renditions.

item.title: Archiving Masters
item.description: If you archive a master when you ingest a video, you will be able to re-transcode the video later without ingesting it again. This topic explains your options for archiving your masters.

item.title: DRM Packages
item.description: If your account is DRM-enabled, you can define DRM packages in your ingest profiles using the packages array.

item.title: Rendition Settings and Video Quality
item.description: Optimizing online video quality and performance is a complex challenge. This topic explains the different factors that affect quality and performance and the rendition settings for your ingest profiles that you can use to get the results you want.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Ingest Profiles API Authentication
item.description: Authentication for API requests depends on the Brightcove OAuth Service. Go to the general OAuth documentation for a full explanation of how it works. Here we will walk through the steps you need to complete to get client credentials and use those in turn to get temporary access tokens for Ingest Profiles API calls.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Multiple Session Playback
item.description: Now a Perform version of this doc: This topic describes how to use the new Brightcove player to update a session cookie during playback to maintain the current position.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Scroll Player into View
item.description: Now a Perform version of this doc: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player which starts playing the video as soon as you fully scroll the player into view, and pauses the video when you scroll it out of view. We call the Brightcove player API's play() and pause() methods to start and stop the video based on the position of the player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Loading the Player Dynamically
item.description: Now a Perform version of this doc: This topic describes how to load the Brightcove player dynamically, that is, on a user event and NOT in the startup HTML. In the working example here you can click the Add Player button to dynamically load the player and play a video.

item.title: Brightcove Player: Featured Playlist
item.description: This topic shows you how to configure a playlist enabled player to start with a video which is not the first video in the playlist. Note: Playlists in Brightcove Player are in beta development. So, the featured playlist plugin is only intended to be a workaround until playlists support this behavior.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Playback API
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com
item.description: NEW API!!: This section provides documentation for accessing your Video Cloud video and playlist data via the Playback API. The Playback API is for use at runtime in web pages or mobile apps - for general media management and integration with other systems, use the CMS API instead. This section also includes the Policy API, which is used to get policy key strings to authenticate requests to the Playback API.

item.title: Player Controls
item.description: This topic explains how to work with the Brightcove Player controls when using the Brightcove Player SDK for Android.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Bumper for Flash or HTML Player
item.description: This sample plays what looks like a preroll bumper clip. It is not a true bumper, because they are always played preroll. Instead, the "bumpers" here are just other video clips from the media library. This allows the "bumper" to work in both Flash and HTML players (provided the "bumper" video has HLS or at least MP4 renditions). The "bumper" is chosen randomly from an array of 2 video ids stored in the long description field of the main video.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for Android Index Page
item.description: New SDK release: 4.4.2

item.title: Custom Endscreen Plugin: Use mailto with video name
item.description: New section added to doc: You may wish to allow the viewer of the video to email you a question or comment. You can do this by using an HTML mailto link in the custom endscreen
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Retrieve all Video Cloud cue point info
item.description: New section added to doc: As you may have noticed not all Video Cloud cue point information is directly available to you from the activecues array. This is easily remedied by retrieving the desired info from the mediainfo property.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Disabling the Progress Scrubber
item.description: This topic shows you how to use a Brightcove player while hiding or disabling the progress scrubber. This may be useful for training videos, where you want users to watch the entire video without the ability to fast-forward through the video using the progress scrubber.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Playback Technology Guide
item.description: New section added to doc: This table shows the expected format to play based on tech order and browser. The tables assumes there are both HLS and MP4 renditions available for a video source.

item.title: Dynamic Ingest API Overview
item.description: Brightcove's Dynamic Ingest (DI) API is based on functionality where video source files are downloaded from the customer's storage location and specified renditions of the source files are created. The platform is cloud-centric, globally-distributed and based on modern practices to deliver best in class consistency and speed.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Dynamic Ingest Fields Reference
item.description: This is a reference to video fields that can be used in the request body JSON for Dynamic Ingest.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Dynamic Ingest API - API Reference
item.description: The Dynamic Ingest (DI) API is used to instruct Video Cloud to retrieve a video asset and create rendtions for it.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Content Security (DRM and HLSe)
item.description: Video Cloud offers several forms of content security, some of which can be used together. This topic deals with security that can be configured in your ingest profiles: *DRM *HLS encryption (HLSe) For additional content security mechanisms that can be set in either the player configuration or video properties, see: *Configuring Player Availability *Configuring Video Availability
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for iOS Index Page
item.description: New SDK release: 4.4.0: *Breaking Changes -Player is now paused when entering the background and therefore no longer resumes automatically when entering the foreground. This was added to work around an AVPlayer play state corruption when becoming active. If you would like to regain the original functionality, you will need to call play on the player when entering the foreground. *Additions and Improvements -Added -[BCOVPlaybackControllerAdsDelegate playbackController:didPauseAd:] and -[BCOVPlaybackControllerAdsDelegate playbackController:didResumeAd:] to be implemented by ad session providers. -Updated to Analytics API v2, including quality of service metrics. -Updated internal ReactiveCocoa version from 2.3.1 to 2.5. -Internal improvements to support BCOVPlayerUI.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Using Playlists
item.description: New section added to doc: Moving the playlist - By default the playlist displays to the right of the video, displaying the videos vertically. This can be changed using CSS, and is described in this section.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Get Status of Dynamic Ingest Requests
item.description: When you use the Dynamic Ingest API to add videos to your Video Cloud account, what you most want to know is when the video has been processed and whether or not renditions were successfully created. This document explains how you can do that using Dynamic Ingest API notifications and the CMS API. We also provide a sample dashboard app that automates the process.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Volume Control
item.description: This topic explains and demonstrates the two methods, muted() and volume(), used to programmatically control audio for Brightcove Player. Of course you can manually control audio using the volume button in the player controls.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Domain Restrictions Messaging
item.description: It is possible to restrict where a video can be viewed via domain restrictions. The Configuring Player Availability document shows you how to use Video Cloud to apply domain restrictions. The document you are now reading instructs you how to implement code to inform users that the player is using domain restrictions.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Add Captions to Videos
item.description: New section added to doc: Styling captions - The default look and feel of the captions is subject to change so you may wish to style the captions. There are a few ways that captions can be styled: *By adding styling options to the WebVTT file *By creating a custom class in a CSS file *CSS style guide *User styling options
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Getting Started with IE8
item.description: This topic discusses how you can run the Brightcove Player In-Page embed code in the IE8 browser. Since the IE8 browser was created before the invention of HTML5 tags, the browser does not know about these tags. Ideally, Microsoft would like users to upgrade to IE9, but this topic will show you a few tips to get the HTML5 video element to play in IE8.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: OAuth Guide
item.description: Brightcove has created an OAuth 2 system that can be used across all of our new APIs for authorization. This topic shows you how to use OAuth to communicate with the Player Management API. You don't need to know anything about OAuth in order to use the system, and we'll explain everything you need to do to get started below. For a detailed overview of OAuth, see the Brightcove OAuth API documents.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: MPEG-DASH Video
item.description: MPEG-DASH is a segmented video format. It is particularly useful if you require DRM security for your content, because DASH can be used with Playready, Marlin, or Widevine Modular DRM. Since the syntax for specifying MPEG-DASH renditions is slightly different than that for other video formats, we include here a couple of sample profiles, one without DRM packaging and the other including DRM packaging.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Ingesting WebVTT Files
item.description: Dynamic Ingest can be used to ingest WebVTT files (for captions, subtitles, chapters, etc.) with your video, or separately, after the video has been ingested. This topic explains the details of adding WebVTT files to your videos using the Dynamic Ingest API.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Images and the Dynamic Ingest API
item.description: There are two different ways to add poster and thumbnail images to your videos using the Dynamic Ingest API: *Capture images at the mid-point of the video during transcoding *Ingest your own images, either at the same time you ingest the video, or separately This topic explains how to capture or ingest images.

item.title: Notifications
item.description: Both the Dynamic Ingest and CMS APIs have notification services. In the case of the Dynamic Ingest API, notifications provide information about the progress of your ingest jobs. The CMS API provides notifications of changes to the videos in your account, whether made by an account user or the Video Cloud system. This document explains how to receive notifications and the kinds of information contained in them.

item.title: Dynamic Ingest Log
item.description: Videos are listed in order of processing completion time, newest to oldest. The reference id (generated by the Dynamic Ingest tester) is a combination of the date/time that the Dynamic Ingest job was initiated and the ingest profile that was used. You can add additional videos using the Dynamic Ingest tester. New videos will appear in this log after processing is complete. You can use code from this GitHub repo to build your own logging app: https://github.com/BrightcoveLearning/dynamic-ingest-dashboard.

item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Once Media Management API
item.description: Major revision: The Media Management API is a RESTful API for accessing and configuring the components of the domain for an authorized user. The multi-faceted and cascading configuration hierarchy gives the domain owner the ability to set-up domain, application, catalog and mediaitem level settings. The authorized user has the ability to create, read, update and delete anything from ad configurations to metadata on independent media items. It provides easy to use methods for fronting UI components in an existing CMS or through a programmatic function.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Once VOD 2.0
item.description: New organization of the Once VOD 2.0 doc into multiple pieces to make it easier to use: http://docs.brightcove.com/en/once/guides/once-vod-2-0.html http://docs.brightcove.com/en/once/guides/content-ingestion-vod-2.html http://docs.brightcove.com/en/once/guides/media-management-vod-2.html http://docs.brightcove.com/en/once/guides/status-vod-2.html
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Once Media Management API
item.description: New format for API reference: The Media Management API is a RESTful API for accessing and configuring the components of the domain for an authorized user. The multi-faceted and cascading configuration hierarchy gives the domain owner the ability to set-up domain, application, catalog and mediaitem level settings. The authorized user has the ability to create, read, update and delete anything from ad configurations to metadata on independent media items. It provides easy to use methods for fronting UI components in an existing CMS or through a programmatic function.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Delivery System API
item.description: New format for API reference: Reference for the Delivery System API, used to manage and deploy a group of files, called a repository. These files are managed through REST APIs and through git. These files are delivered, on every git push, to players.brightcove.com.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Player Management API
item.description: New format for API reference: Reference for the Brightcove Player - Player Management API, used to manipulate players, player configurations and child players (embeds).

item.title: Dynamic Ingest - Re-transcode Multiple Videos
item.description: This is a sample of retranscoding of videos using the Dynamic Ingest API. The Dynamic Ingest API call is exactly the same as it would be for ingesting new videos - the only difference is that you do not need to make a prior call to the CMS API to create the video object in the Video Cloud system and get an id for it, and the request body is slightly different. All videos will remain playable with existing renditions until retranscoding is complete.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: CMS API Video Fields Reference
item.description: New fileds added: This is a reference to video fields returned by the CMS API.

item.title: Analytics API v1 Overview
item.description: Greatly expanded the valid dimension combinations section, with important information about the earliest date that can be used in date-range for each combination - The Analytics API allows you to obtain analytics data for your Video Cloud accounts directly. You can also view the built-in analytics reports in the Analytics Module of Video Cloud Studio. Accessing the data programmatically gives you additional flexibility for such purposes as: * Creating custom charts and displays * Working with multiple APIs together - for example, getting video data using the CMS API for videos with the most views over the previous week * Combining your video analytic data with other site analytics data
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Migrating from the Media API to the CMS API
item.description: This topic provides guidance on migrating your apps from the Media API to the CMS API. There are several good reasons why you should migrate to the CMS API. * The CMS API provides cacheless read access to your video and playlist data, so you always get the latest data * The CMS API provides functionality and data that are not available via the Media API * We are actively working on enhancing the functionality and performance of the CMS API, while the Media API is in maintenance mode, and no further enhancements are planned * The Brightcove OAuth service used by the CMS API provides a greater level of security and more granular access control
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

The player position will then remain fixed even when the user scrolls up and down the page. There is a working sample in this page, so try it out, and then read on to see how it is done.

It then remains in that position while you scroll up and down the page.

item.title: Fallback / Retry Strategy
item.description: Dynamic Ingest imposes rate-limiting (per account) in two ways: *No more than 10 requests (CMS API and/or Ingest API requests) per second are allowed *No more than 100 concurrent jobs are allowed; The first is not difficult to manage in your app - you can just impose a delay of .1 seconds or more between requests. The second is more complicated, as there is no way to query the system directly to determine how many jobs you have currently processing.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Select Rendition for Playback
item.description: This topic shows you how to select the best quality MP4 rendition of a video loaded in Brightcove Player and set it as the source to playback. The code will be written and explained, then later in the document converted into a plugin for easy use with different players.

item.title: Using Dynamic Ingest with S3
item.description: Modified sample policy to allow for image/webvtt ingest: Dynamic Ingest can pull videos from your Amazon S3 bucket. If your S3 content is accessible to Everyone, there is nothing you need to do. If your content is protected, however, you will need to add a bucket policy allowing Dynamic Ingest to access your videos. This document explains how to do that.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Generate Video Sitemaps
item.description: There is a standard document called a sitemap that search engine indexers look for when examining your site. The sitemap concisely tells the search engines what content is exposed on your site, the metadata for that content, and where that content is located on your site. A sitemap is an XML file that follows a standard specification.

item.description: Different plugins are needed for the different versions of Brightcove Player. This document tracks player and plugin versions compatibility.

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Loading the Player Dynamically
item.description: Added section on using the bc() method: There are times where you will want to the use the bc() method to dynamically instantiate the player rather than the method show above. You will want to use the bc() method when you wish to load the player's JavaScript before the video element is loaded into the DOM. If you use the videojs() method NOT in conjunction with bc(), you will get the Video.js player, but without the customizations that are added by Brightcove Player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Sample: Custom Event
item.description: This topic shows you how to dispatch and listen for a custom event. Even though the Brightcove player provides a number of out-of-the-box events, you may want to use your own custom events to decouple and eliminate dependencies between DOM objects and event listeners. This event-driven model is an architectural choice that you may want to consider. This sample adds a back button to the control bar. When the user clicks the back button, a custom event is triggered along with the amount of time to rewind. The custom event listener finds the current video position and rewinds the video.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: HLS Plugin Guide
item.description: Minor, but crucial, update. Info on Media Source Extensions and 608 captions. - The HLS plugin is a Brightcove player plugin that relies on W3C's Media Source Extensions (MSE) to play HLS video on platforms that do not natively support it. The HLS plugin is automatically included in the player.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

This document is furnished as a convenience only and not necessarily maintained. The Google Analytics plugin sends player and video event data to your Google Analytics account. While Brightcove Analytics provides key metrics about user engagement, you may also want to integrate your player with Google Analytics. One advantage is that you can generate an AdWords remarketing list.

The cue points are configured in Studio with the cue point Metadata property holding a semicolon delimited list of strings that contain information for the CTA. For this sample, the duration of the CTA, text for the CTA and the link for the CTA are stored in the metadata field of the cue point.

item.description: Brightcove's CMS API allows you to delete specific renditions from videos. You may wish to do this to reduce the number of renditions that are stored, particularly if you have migrated from the old Smart Player to the Brightcove Player, and have FLV or other renditions that are not used by the Brightcove Player. You might also want to remove renditions that are rarely if ever played, because the bitrate is too high or low.

item.description: To share videos created with Dynamic Ingest, the Media API is used. The sharing account must have â€œshare by referenceâ€ enabled - contact Brightcove Support to verify this. This means the share API request can be made before transcoding has completed.

item.title: Using the CMS API: Add WebVTT Captions
item.description: Doc updated to clarify how WebVTT assets are handled for remote asset videos (exactly the same as they are for ingested videos) - Brightcove's CMS API allows you to add WebVTT captions to your video metadata. Note that WebVTT captions cannot be added when you initially create the video using a POST request. Instead they must be added using a PATCH request to update the video metadata. See Batch Update Using CMS API for an example of an update request. API doc also updated: http://docs.brightcove.com/en/video-cloud/cms-api/references/cms-api/versions/v1/index.html#api-videoGroup-Update_Video

item.title: Smart Player to Brightcove Player Migration Guide
item.description: Major update - The Brightcove Player, which replaces the Smart Player, is an HTML-first video player that will deliver video entirely through HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in almost all cases. It is also considerably lighter and loads faster than the Smart Player, and it has a more robust plugin architecture that allows a broader range of customizations. Because of this and the fact that the internet is rapidly moving away from Flash, you are encouraged to migrate your content to the Brightcove Player as soon as it is practical to do so.

item.title: Directed Migration
item.description: The Directed Migration Framework is a way to specify a Brightcove Player to be loaded instead of one or more Smart Players. To use Directed Migration, you still must create a new Brightcove Player that has the customizations and plugins that match the behavior you want using the new APIs and plugins of the Brightcove Player. Directed Migration then allows you to load that new player in place of a Smart Player without making changes to the existing HTML page.

item.title: Brightcove Player SDK for iOS: Code Snippets
item.description: Buffer size - You may consider increasing the buffer length to eliminate buffering in the player if the delivery of the next segment is delayed from the CDN. But, you may not be able to do anything better manually that HLS already does. HLS is designed to play right away and drop quality if it can't keep up. This way, it does not need to preload a buffer. If it can't keep up, it will load as much of the video as it can at the best quality to prevent interruption.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Notifications

This document explains how to receive notifications and the kinds of information contained in them. Both API references have also been updated appropriately.

item.title: Overview: Analytics API v1
item.description: Updated for new dimensions (browser_type and device_manufacturer) and also added links to all the detailed dimension guides.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: account Dimension
item.description: The account dimension is used to retrieve overall analytics data for the account.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: city Dimension
item.description: The city dimension returns analytics data by city.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: country Dimension
item.description: The country dimension returns analytics data by country.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: region Dimension
item.description: The region domain provides information about where videos were viewed. It returns ISO-3611-2 region codes (example: US-WA). How regions are defined varies by country.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: date Dimension
item.description: The date dimension returns analytics for a single day. The user can specify the from and to parameters in yyyy-mm-dd format. This enables a user to query the analytics system to generate report report by days within the from and to date range. Any date range specified by the user will be interpreted to the current timezone for the account. The date ranges for the request are inclusive, exclusive i.e. if the user makes a request from=2013-09-24&to=2013-09-27, the response will include results from 2013-09-24 00:00:00 to 2013-09-27 00:00:00.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: date_hour Dimension
item.description: The date_hour dimension provides analytics data in hourly segments. The user can specify the from and to parameters in yyyy-MM-dd or epoch time in milliseconds format. To report over a span of hours, you will need to use the milliseconds format, with to and from values falling within the start and end hours that you want to query on. Any date range specified by the user will be interpreted to the current timezone for the account. date_hour reports are only valid for ranges within the past 32 days. If the from value is more than 32 days ago, an error will be returned.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: destination_domain Dimension
item.description: The destination_domain dimension provides the domain where video views occurred.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: destination_path Dimension
item.description: The destination_path dimension provides the path where video views occurred. It is generally used together with the destination_domain dimension.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: device_os Dimension
item.description: The device_manufacturer dimension provides information about the manufacturer of the device that videos were viewed on. Note for these values: blackberry (inlude RIM); lenova (includes Motorola); microsoft (includes Nokia); sony (includes Ericsson).
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: device_type Dimension
item.description: The device_type dimension provides information about the type of the device that videos were viewed on.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: player Dimension
item.description: The player dimension provides analytics for video players.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: referrer_domain Dimension
item.description: The referrer_domain dimension is the top private domain of the referrer URL on a page where events are collected for analytics.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: search_terms Dimension
item.description: The search_terms dimension is the keywords used if the traffic source that resulted in events being collected for activity metrics was a search engine, and the keywords are detectable.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: source_type Dimension
item.description: The source_type is the type of traffic source that resulted in events being collected for analytics.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: video Dimension
item.description: The video dimension provides analytics by video.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

The Analytics API allows you to obtain analytics data for your Video Cloud accounts directly. You can also view the built-in analytics reports in the Analytics Module of Video Cloud Studio. Accessing the data programmatically gives you additional flexibility.

item.description: Updated to show how to remove/replace text tracks via the CMS API - In this topic, you will learn how to use the CMS API to add WebVTT text tracks for captions or chapters to your videos. Note that WebVTT captions cannot be added when you initially create the video using a POST request. Instead they must be added using a PATCH request to update the video metadata. See Update Using Videos Using the CMS API for an example of an update request.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Search for Videos
item.description: Updated to show how to search for clips in a video library - In this topic, you will learn how to search for videos in your account using the CMS API. item.title: Announcement: iOS SDK EOL support for iOS 7 and deprecating support for iOS 8
item.description: As of version 5.2.0, the Brightcove Native Player SDK for iOS will be removing support for iOS7 and deprecating support for iOS8. Apple continually makes updates to its iOS operating system, which affects the technology that the Brightcove SDK is built around. In order to focus on cutting edge features, we must evolve alongside Apple by providing support for only the relevant versions of iOS.

item.description: In this topic, you will first get a high level overview of using the REST APIs. Then later in the document a deeper dive will discuss example code. The first example uses the Analytics API to retrieve and display in the player's controlbar the number of views the video currently in the player has had. The second, and slightly more complex, example uses the Analytics API in conjunction with the Brightcove Player catalog to retrieve the most popular videos from an account and show them in a playlist. The code discussion in this document will center on retrieving the desired data from the correct REST API.

item.title: Flash No Longer Valid with IMA
item.description: Google has ceased supporting the IMA SDK for Flash and Flash VPAID ads in the HTML5 SDK, because of this ad networks and browsers are quickly removing support for Flash. To make sure ads continue to play and your Brightcove Players don't pause to ask viewers to install Flash, you should check to be sure your players are configured correctly.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Brightcove Player Version 6 Released
item.description: Brightcove Player 6 is now the default version for newly created players, a major version update. A change to the major version indicates a significant change to the way the API works, and a few of the changes Brightcove made to simplify the API could break some integration code. Because of this, and in order to prevent problems with your site, automatic updates will not be made for major version updates. That means that your player will effectively be locked at the final release of Brightcove Player version 5, even if you have selected automatic update mode. You will need to manually update to Brightcove Player 6 once your testing is complete.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Publishing a Video to Salesforce Chatter
item.description: In this topic you will learn how to publish videos inside of Salesforce Chatter. Salesforce Chatter is a tool inside of Salesforce that can be used for collaboration and knowledge sharing. Video Cloud videos can be published inside Salesforce Chatter. Salesforce Chatter uses a service to whitelist video players and Brightcove is listed with this service. To post a Video Cloud video inside of Chatter all you need to do is generate a link to the video and then post it inside of Chatter.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Advertising with the IMA3 Plugin
item.description: Very important new information for those who configure the IMA3 plugin using JavaScript: In the code below, you see the bc() method is called to initialize the Brightcove Player, then the IMA3 plugin is initialized immediately thereafter. This is because for the IMA3 plugin to function properly it needs to be loaded right after player initialization, before any other plugins are initialized. Initializing the IMA3 plugin in videojs('myPlayerID').ready(...) or when the loadedmetadata event is dispatched, will cause the plugin to NOT function as intended.

This can also be done with the CMS API, but using the Playback API allows you to create a pure client-side app, without having to route the API request through a server-side proxy.

item.title: Zencoder Using Quality-Based Encoding Modes For Streaming Video
item.description: When encoding video outputs for streaming, we do not recommend using quality setting alone (this uses CRF mode of encoding). If you prefer to use quality-targeted mode then we strongly suggest using VBV settings to constrain the variation in bitrate to comply with streaming format specifications.
item.author: rcrooks@brightcove.com

item.title: Zencoder HTTP Live Streaming using fragmented MP4
item.description: Please refer to HTTP Live (Segmented) Streaming and Playlists for more details on ts outputs and playlists. To choose fragmented MP4 files with HLS outputs, use "format": "m4f" and "streaming_delivery_format": "hls". We highly recommend setting "byte_range_segmenting": true, to format the media as a single fragmented MP4 file rather than having separate segment files.
